60‑Day Community Engagement Blueprint — Miami‑Dade Rollout

A Relationship‑Driven Growth Plan for Pediatric & Diagnostic Provider Networks.
Prepared by Matthew James Carbonell (Candidate), Community Engagement Manager
Miami, FL · matthewjamescarbonell@gmail.com
305‑764‑2999 · linkedin.com/in/matthew-carbonell-a73b1b230

Kyo expands access to high‑quality ABA therapy and makes every moment count for families. This plan launches a trusted, bilingual referral pipeline—delivered with empathy, measured by data, and sustained through provider partnerships.

This plan illustrates how I would translate Kyo’s mission into measurable community impact within the first 60 days of hire.

This plan represents a candidate‑generated proposal and may be adapted to Kyo’s operational standards upon hire.

Access

Reduce barriers for families seeking ABA (language, logistics, payor).

Awareness

Position Kyo as the trusted provider among pediatric and diagnostic networks.

Advocacy

Champion early identification and continuity of care.

1Territory Insight Snapshot

Focus ZIPs (illustrative)

Kendall • Doral • Hialeah • North Miami • Homestead

Low Medium High
  • High density of family‑oriented clinics; bilingual communication (Spanish/Haitian Creole) required.
  • Key corridors: pediatric hubs near major hospitals/health systems; school‑adjacent clusters.
  • Parent & nonprofit ecosystems (autism orgs, CARD‑style centers, school ESE networks) create fast reach.
  • Competitor activity present → we’ll differentiate on empathy + throughput + transparent communication.

Data references: Florida DOH Provider Database, U.S. Census Bureau ACS 2023, Miami‑Dade Pediatric Practice Index.

Strategic takeaway: Launch bilingual, hyperlocal outreach in provider clusters near children’s hospitals and school corridors; prioritize providers with demonstrated ASD screening volumes and open capacity.

2Objectives & OKRs

Objective 1 – Build a durable referral pipeline

  • KR1: Establish 15–20 new active provider relationships (A/B‑tier) by Day 60.
  • KR2: Improve referral response time to ≤48 hours and grow referral volume by 20% from baseline.

Objective 2 – Community Visibility & Content Activation

  • KR4: Execute 1 sensory‑friendly, bilingual community event (≥100 participants) with co‑hosts.
  • KR5: Deploy a bilingual content micro‑series (“ABA in 60 Seconds”) with 6 pieces published.

Objective 3 – Institute measurement & continuous improvement

  • KR6: Stand‑up a weekly dashboard (Referrals, Providers Active, Conversion %, Response SLA).
  • KR7: Complete 2 monthly WBRs (Weekly Business Review → Month‑end rollups) with insights & next tests.

3Plan at a Glance

Phase 1 — Assessment & Foundation (Days 1–30)

Goal: Build operational readiness through relationship mapping, CRM clarity, and collateral creation.

Actions

  • Stakeholder interviews: Regional Director, Intake, BCBA Lead, Scheduling, Payor Relations, Marketing.
  • CRM audit: referral sources, cycle time from referral→intake→treatment plan, drop‑off points.
  • Market build: ID top 50 providers (pediatrics, developmental‑behavioral, neuro, psych, school counselors).
  • Provider scoring: Potential (0–3), Openness (0–3), Alignment (0–3) ⇒ POA score / 9; prioritize ≥7.
  • Collateral: bilingual clinic packet (1‑pager, referral form, QR), ABA FAQ (plain language), HIPAA‑safe talking points.
  • KPI set: weekly tracker + baseline numbers; define SLAs (first‑touch ≤24–48 hrs; follow‑up cadence).

Milestones

  • Provider list segmented (A/B/C tiers), route plan mapped.
  • CRM fields standardized (see Data Model below).
  • Baseline dashboard draft running.

Phase 2 — Activation & Growth (Days 31–60)

Goal: Activate the field plan through visits, content, and measurable referral conversion.

Actions

  • Provider meetings: 20–30 visits across A/B tiers with bilingual packets & follow‑ups (phone/email).
  • Community event: Host/co‑host (e.g., autism resource fair, family Q&A, school partner night); ensure sensory‑friendly setup.
  • Email cadence: weekly provider updates (2 versions: “new partner” vs “active partner”).
  • Content: 6 “ABA in 60 Seconds” bilingual posts (myth‑busting, onboarding steps, contact paths).
  • Feedback loops: biweekly check‑ins with top referrers; log insights & friction (payor/prior auth/capacity).

Targets

  • +20% referrals vs. baseline.
  • 15–20 new active providers.
  • Response time ≤48 hours.
  • 1 event ≥100 participants; 3 partnership confirmations (clinic, nonprofit, school).

6Territory Data Model (CRM)

Entities

Account (Provider): Name, Type (Pediatrics / DBP / Neuro / Psych / School / Other), POA score (0–9), Language, Location/ZIP, Payor familiarity (Medicaid/Commercial), Notes.

Contact: Name, Role (MD/Office Mgr/Screener), Email/Phone, Preferred Lang, Opt‑in.

Activity: Visit/Call/Email, Date, Outcome, Next Step (date/time), Owner.

Referral: Date, Source Provider (lookup), Family Contacted Y/N, First‑Touch Time (hrs), Intake Scheduled (Y/N + date), Conversion Outcome, Notes.

Event: Name, Date, Host(s), Attendance, Leads captured, Post‑event follow‑ups.

Stage Definitions

Lead (provider known) → Prospect (meeting booked) → Active (≥1 referral in 30 days) → Retained (≥1 referral in 60 days).

7Provider Segmentation & Route Plan

POA Scoring: Potential (0–3): ASD screening volume, patient mix, clinic size. Openness (0–3): Responsiveness, interest, prior interactions. Alignment (0–3): Values match, bilingual need, location adjacency, payor mix.

Prioritize: POA ≥7; build weekly route with 4–5 visits across clustered ZIPs (optimize drive time).

System Integration: Ensure compatibility with Salesforce Health Cloud or HubSpot CRM; use standardized field mapping for data integrity.

8Scripts & Templates

A) 15‑minute intro script (provider) — English

“Dr. ___, I’m Matthew with Kyo. We partner with pediatric and diagnostic teams to make ABA access simple and compassionate for families. I brought a 1‑page overview and a referral QR so your team can reach us without PHI. We report back on outcomes you care about: speed to first contact, scheduled intakes, and family satisfaction. May I learn what matters most to your clinic when referring for ABA?”

B) 15‑minute intro script — Español

“Doctora ___, soy Matthew de Kyo. Trabajamos con pediatras y especialistas para facilitar el acceso a ABA de manera compasiva. Traje un resumen y un código QR para referir sin compartir información médica. También enviamos actualizaciones: tiempo de respuesta, citas programadas y satisfacción de las familias. ¿Qué es lo más importante para su clínica al referir a ABA?”

Language calibrated for neutral Latin American Spanish to maximize inclusivity in Miami‑Dade.

C) Front desk ask (short)

“Who handles referrals for developmental services, and may I leave a bilingual sheet + QR for them?”

D) Email (new partner) — English

Subject: Quick ABA access for your families — Kyo Miami (referral QR inside)
Body (4 lines): thanks, 1‑page PDF link, QR, SLA (“We call within 24–48 hrs.”), contact line.

E) Email (active partner) — English

Subject: 2‑minute Kyo update: your referrals & next steps
Body: brief metrics (“3 referrals; 2 intakes scheduled; 1 pending benefits”), note on family needs, next week’s clinic visit times.

9Collateral Kit (bilingual, HIPAA‑safe)

  • ABA Fast Facts (1‑pager): what ABA is, how we individualize, onboarding steps, “no PHI on referral.”
  • Referral QR card: scan → web form without PHI; fields = provider contact + family name/phone consent only (intake gathers PHI later).
  • Event leaflets: sensory‑friendly note, short “what to expect”; alt‑text for digital assets.
  • Teaser video: “ABA in 60 Seconds” x6 scripts (myth‑busts + call to action).

Compliance & Ethics

HIPAA: Do not request or receive PHI during outreach; use consent‑based intake pathways only.

Anti‑Kickback/Stark: No inducements for referrals; educational materials only; fair‑market value for any sponsored activities.

FERPA: If engaging schools, protect student info; obtain proper consents.

10Events — Sensory‑Friendly Checklist

  • Quiet corner + noise‑reducing headphones.
  • Visual schedule / social story handout.
  • Bilingual signage & materials; clear wayfinding.
  • Trained staff/volunteers for gentle de‑escalation.
  • Post‑event follow‑up within 48 hrs (providers & families).

6Event execution + reportingEvent (≥100); post‑event follow‑ups; Week‑6 WBR
7Optimization + provider healthWin/loss review; deepen A‑tier; video batch 2
860‑day readoutKPI deltas; lessons; next‑quarter tests & targets

WBR (Weekly Business Review) doc: 1‑page—wins, risks, pipeline health, actions for next week.

12Tangible Outputs at Day 60

  • Provider database (segmented + route plan).
  • Bilingual collateral kit (PDFs + QR).
  • Dashboard (live weekly; 2 month‑end rollups).
  • Event (recap + leads + follow‑ups).
  • Readout (what worked, what didn’t, top tests for next 90 days).
  • 90‑Day Roadmap (draft) with retention and partnership KPIs for Q2.

Presentation Tips: Export as PDF/A High Quality; embed fonts. Maintain blue rule frame + right‑aligned footer to match letter/resume. In the email, add: “Portfolio link includes bilingual samples, CRM field dictionary, and dashboard mockups.”

13Micro‑Appendix — 90‑Day Vision

  • Provider retention campaign and recognition program.
  • Bilingual parent‑education workshops (monthly webinar).
  • Quarterly public impact dashboard for stakeholders.
